gb-not-download.content:
If you’ve started to download one or more Learn to Play lessons, and the download is interrupted or is incomplete, use the following steps to complete the download or re-download your lesson.

If your lesson doesn’t finish downloading:

  1. Check your network connection. Your network connection must be active for the download to complete.

    After you verify that your network connection is active, follow the remaining steps.

  2. Close and reopen GarageBand. If GarageBand is already closed, click its icon to open it. An alert appears indicating that the download will resume.

  3. If GarageBand is open but the Project Chooser isn’t visible, choose File > New to open it.

  4. In the Project Chooser, click “Learn to Play,” then click the arrow in the lower-right corner to resume the download.

  5. If you’re still unable to complete the download, open your web browser, go to http://store.apple.com, and click Help. On the Help page, see the “Downloadable Software Purchases” area for information and instructions on how to re-download your lesson.
gb-not-download.name: If your lesson doesn’t finish downloading
gb-not-download.summary: If your download is interrupted, you can take steps to complete it.

gbnd2a89754b.content:
When you add a track by clicking the Add Track button or choosing Track > New Track, the New Track dialog appears. In the New Track dialog, you select the type of track you want to add: a Software Instrument, Real Instrument, or Electric Guitar track.

For Real Instrument and Electric Guitar tracks, you can choose the audio input and input channel for the track, and turn on monitoring for the track. You can also choose the audio output for GarageBand–the entire project, not only the new track.

To select the type of track to add:

  • Click one of the three areas in the upper part of the window, for a Software Instrument, Real Instrument, or Electric Guitar track.

To show the input, output, and monitoring controls:

  • Click the triangle next to Instrument Setup.

To set the audio input for a Real Instrument or Electric Guitar track:

  • Choose an audio input from the upper-left pop-up menu. If you are using the microphone built into your computer, choose Built-in Microphone. If your microphone or instrument is connected to an audio input port on your computer, choose Line-In. If you are using an audio interface, choose the audio interface.

To set the input channel for a Real Instrument or Electric Guitar track:

  • Choose the input channel from the lower-left pop-up menu. If your instrument is connected to your computer with a single (monophonic) cable, choose a Mono input source. If your instrument is connected with a pair of stereo cables, choose a Stereo input source.

To set the audio output for GarageBand:

  • Choose an audio output from the upper-right pop-up menu.

To turn on monitoring for the track:

  • Select the “I want to hear my instrument as I play and record” checkbox.

To create the new track with your chosen settings:

  • Click Create.
gbnd2a89754b.name: Add a new track
gbnd2a89754b.summary: Choose the track type, and set the audio input and output.

gbnd8e539c73.content:
You can hear, or “monitor,” the input from a microphone while you play and record in GarageBand. When you turn on monitoring for a track, you hear the instrument or microphone connected to the track’s input. Monitoring lets you hear your part along with the rest of the project as you play. In some situations, particularly when using your computer’s speakers instead of headphones, you may want to turn monitoring off to avoid feedback.

To turn monitoring on or off:

  • From the Monitor pop-up menu, choose one of the following:

    • Choose Off to turn off monitoring. You can hear your instrument only while you record.

    • Choose On to turn on monitoring and protect against feedback. If feedback occurs, an alert appears, asking if you want to turn monitoring off while you determine what is causing the feedback.

    • Choose On (no feedback protection) to turn on monitoring without feedback protection. If the input level is too high, it may cause feedback (especially if you are using a microphone and listening to your project through your computer speakers).

You can also turn monitoring on or off in the track’s header by choosing Track > Show Monitoring for Real Instrument Tracks, and then clicking the Monitor button in the track’s header.
gbnd8e539c73.name: Turn monitoring on or off for a microphone
gbnd8e539c73.summary: Turn on monitoring so you can hear sound from your microphone.

gbnd8e539d91.content:
You can hear, or “monitor,” the input from a guitar while you play and record in GarageBand. When you turn on monitoring for a track, you hear the guitar connected to the track’s input. Monitoring lets you hear yourself as you play so that you can hear your part along with the rest of the project. In some situations, particularly when using your computer’s speakers instead of headphones, you may want to turn monitoring off to avoid feedback.

To turn monitoring on or off:

  • From the Monitor pop-up menu, choose one of the following:

    • Choose Off to turn off monitoring. You can hear your instrument only while you record.

    • Choose On to turn on monitoring and protect against feedback. If feedback occurs, an alert appears, asking if you want to turn monitoring off while you determine what is causing the feedback.

    • Choose On (no feedback protection) to turn on monitoring without feedback protection. If the input level is too high, it may cause feedback.

You can also turn monitoring on or off in the track’s header by clicking the Monitor button in the track’s header.
gbnd8e539d91.name: Turn monitoring on or off for an electric guitar
gbnd8e539d91.summary: Turn on monitoring so you can hear sound from your electric guitar.

gbnd8e53a301.content:
To hear sound from your electric guitar in GarageBand, you must set the input source for the guitar. You can set the input source when you add a track, or set it for the selected track in the Track Info pane.

To set the input source for an electric guitar:

  1. In the Track Info pane, click the amp to select it.

  2. Click Edit.

  3. Do one of the following:

    • If the guitar is connected to the audio input port, choose Built-in Input from the Input Source pop-up menu.

    • If your guitar is connected to an audio interface, choose the channel number the guitar is connected to from the Input Source menu.

      If the audio interface channels do not appear in the menu, choose GarageBand > Preferences, click Audio/MIDI, then choose the audio interface from the Audio Input pop-up menu.

      Make sure the format matches the guitar output. Unless the guitar has stereo output, choose a Mono (monophonic) channel.

  4. Drag the Recording Level slider to change the input volume level.

    If the Recording Level slider is dimmed in the Track Info pane, the input volume can’t be changed in GarageBand. In this case, use the volume control on your guitar or audio interface.
gbnd8e53a301.name: Set the input source for an electric guitar
gbnd8e53a301.summary: Set the audio input source so you can hear sound while you play and record your electric guitar.

gbnd8e53a40e.content:
To hear sound from your microphone in GarageBand, you must set the input source for the microphone. You can set the input source when you add a track, or set it for the selected track in the Track Info pane.

To set the input source for a microphone:

  1. In the Track Info pane, do one of the following:

    • If you are using your computer’s built-in microphone, choose Built-In Microphone from the Input Source pop-up menu.

    • If you are using a microphone connected to your computer’s audio input port or a USB port, choose Built-in Input from the Input Source pop-up menu.

    • If you are using a microphone connected to an audio interface, choose the channel number for the microphone from the Input Source menu.

      Make sure the format matches the microphone. If the microphone has stereo output, choose a Stereo pair of channels; otherwise, choose a Mono (monophonic) channel.

      If the input source does not appear in the menu, choose GarageBand > Preferences, click Audio/MIDI, then choose the input source from the Audio Input pop-up menu.

  2. Drag the Recording Level slider to change the input volume level.

    If the Recording Level slider is dimmed in the Track Info pane, the input volume can’t be changed in GarageBand. In this case, use the device’s own volume control.
gbnd8e53a40e.name: Set the input source for a microphone
gbnd8e53a40e.summary: Set the audio input source so you can record sound using a microphone.

gbnda17359bc.name: If the sound drops out when you play a project

gbnda1735e20.content:
Many familiar sounds in music are created using audio effects. In a GarageBand project, each individual track has a set of built-in effects, including Compressor and Visual EQ. Real Instrument and Electric Guitar tracks also have a Noise Gate effect to minimize low-level noise. The master track includes Master Echo and Master Reverb as well as Visual EQ and Compressor effects.

You can turn effects on or off, choose effect presets, adjust effect settings, reorder effects, and add up to four additional effects to each track in the Track Info pane.

To add and adjust effects:

  1. Double-click the track’s header to open the Track Info pane.

  2. Click Edit to show the track’s effects (for Electric Guitar tracks, select the amp before clicking Edit).

  3. Click the rectangular LED on the left side of an effect to turn the effect on or off.

  4. Choose a new effect preset from the pop-up menu below the effect name. Presets have names that help you understand their intended use.

  5. Add an effect by clicking an empty effect slot, then choose an effect preset from the pop-up menu that appears.

  6. Reorder effects by dragging them up or down by their handles (three vertical dots) in the Effects tab.

    Changing the order of effects can change the sound dramatically, especially for the Amp Simulation, Distortion, and Overdrive effects.

Each project has two master effects, Echo and Reverb. The Master Echo and Master Reverb sliders on individual tracks control how much of the Echo and Reverb effects from the master track are applied to the individual track. If you turn off Echo or Reverb in the master track, these sliders are unavailable for individual tracks.

Electric Guitar tracks also have stompbox effects that you can use to modify the sound of a guitar.

See also
Edit effect presets
Use the Visual EQ effect
Add stompbox guitar effects
Adjust effects for the overall project
Save a track instrument
gbnda1735e20.name: Add and adjust effects

gbnda17380bb.name: Adjust effects for the overall project

gbnda17384fd.content:
You can create changes over time to volume, pan, and other settings using automation. You can add automation to any track, including the master track.

Each instrument track in a project has automation curves for volume and pan, and you can add curves to automate effects settings. To create changes over time, you show the automation curve you want to work on, add control points to the curve at the start and end points for the change you want, and then drag the end point to a new value. The value of the setting changes between the start and end control points.

The master track has automation curves that let you automate volume, pitch, and tempo for the overall project. To add automation to the master track, you show the master track, choose a curve to edit, and then add and adjust control points, just as you do for an automation curve on an instrument track. You can also automate effects settings for the master track using the master automation curves.

See also
Show track automation curves
Add and adjust control points
Automate effects settings
gbnda17384fd.name: Add automation to a track
gbnda17384fd.summary: You can add volume and pan changes over time using volume and pan curves.
